reviewText: Calling this a movie is probably not correct, it is just a longer episode in the series. Trying to watch it as a stand alone movie would not be practical, as the first episodes of the series contain all the character development, and develope the story. The negative reviews sadly did just this, watching only the movie. What they did was open a book half way through it, then complain the characters weren't developed and you know nothing about the story. The movies end without explaining because it was already explained, and there is another movie coming out to tie up the loose ends in this one. Please, do not pick up the movie believing you can watch it without watching the series. If you loved the series, you will love the movie. It picks up where it left off and moves on, and the end (just like the series) leaves you wanting more. Luckily, the next movie is coming soon. Here we even learn more about the "hero's" past, that make you go o yeah from things that were said in the first episodes.

reviewText: This is "King of Eden" the first "Eden of the East" movie, part two of "Eden of the East" over all. "Paradise Lost" will be the last part of the series. I liked the TV series, it had a very unique premise and was gorgeous looking. The movie still looks fantastic, but it feels like it's treading water until it can reach it's conclusion in the next movie.The movie picks up six months after the end of the TV series with Saki in New York looking for Takizawa. There's very little to say without resorting to spoilers. Will Saki find Taki? Will Taki return to Japan? Were you born yesterday?Nothing happens. Or it feels like nothing happens.The TV series felt like a long movie. Ironically, the movie feels like a long episode. Again, the plot is so thin, I can't say anything without it being a spoiler.The problem with series like these is that it can feel like "in for a penny, in for a pound." You already got the series, you're going to talk yourself into spending money on the movies. But, if you're one of those people that HASN'T bought the TV series, and you're waiting to see if the whole series is worth owning, this movie doesn't automatically put "Eden of the East" into the "must buy" pile. Unless "Paradise Lost" caps the series off with something great, I think Eden is going to be a middling "maybe" show.Lastly, I have to complain about the packaging. This is a Blu-Ray, but it comes in a DVD box. So, when I stand this next to the TV series, they don't match. There's currently no option to get this in a blu-ray box. Plus, my arch-nemesis, tiny-blu-ray-menus, continue to run unabated. Who is the hawk-eyed bastard that programs these things?I gave the series a Four. This isn't as good as the series. Three-Stars.
summary: The King of Eden is a Pauper

reviewText: This is part one of basically a two part movie. Not a lot of the 'mythology' is answered in part one, it's more about being in New York City. I'd say the animation is slightly better than the series animation. The first half of the movie is slower because it's all about getting the principles back together and getting them up to speed, so the second half is when we start to progress the story and get back to the game. When the film ends and they head back to Japan in part two.It's part two when basically everything is answered, Takizawa's mother and how they separated, the voices behind Juiz, why Takizawa was picked for the game, the game ends,Mr. Outside, The supporter, Saki, etc. Also in part two at the END of the credits, there is one new scene that addresses an issue from the series.Also the Anime is breathtaking the Picture is as good as it gets on blu ray a must own for any fan of anime.
summary: Good but Waiting for the Next movie Stinks!!!

reviewText: I decided to buy and look into this anime (and its two feature-length movie continuations) for two reasons: one, the animation looked gorgeous, and two, the plot sounded very intriguing and original. While I can say that it did fulfill both of those expectations, it didn't quite reach the heights it seemed like it could have.I won't spoil anything here and I won't bother giving a plot synopsis because you can read it on here already; what I will say is that the mysteries are all enticing at first, but like so many mysteries, the answers don't live up to the questions. After learning the truth behind the plot, I was excited for where the show could go with it, but it... didn't, really.The plot sort of fumbles along without really taking advantage of the tools it's set up, and in the end it leaves you feeling unsatisfied. The two sequel movies are absolutely necessary if you care at all about the story or closure, but even with them you'll probably feel disappointed. This is simply my opinion, however - you may find something here that I didn't.On the plus side, the characters are pretty great (except for the protagonist during "King of Eden", who is very lacking in personality for that movie only for reasons that will be clear if you watch it), and their interactions are very real. The mystery, while it lasts, is intriguing enough to keep you watching to learn more, even if you're ultimately unsatisfied with the denouement. The animation and artwork are beautiful and the music is good enough.Overall, I think that Eden of the East is worth a watch for those curious, but not worth a purchase unless you just really take to it. It's an entertaining enough ride, but at the end of the day it never reaches the heights or importance of "Ghost in the Shell" despite purporting to be similar, and so it's best enjoyed as one would enjoy something like the "Bourne" movies - an entertaining but ultimately shallow experience that's fun while it lasts, but leaves little impact.

reviewerName: JPL "Avid Gamer, Anime, Manga and Movie Enthu...
reviewText: After watching the original series, I became a huge fan of Eden of the East and could not wait until I saw the two theatrical movies to finish off the series: "The King of Eden" and "Paradise Lost."This movie, "The King of Eden" takes place 6 months after the end of the original series. Saki sets out to find Takizawa who has gone missing since his wish to become King of Japan and once again erasing his memories. All Saki  has to go on is a message that Takizawa left on his Selecao cell phone for her - that she will always find him at their "special place" (or that place where they travelled together according to the English Subs) which in her interpretation leads her to New  York City. Meanwhile, the Eden of the East search site has exploded in popularity since the missle attacks and our Neets are now running a full fledged corporation. However, as a result of the missile attacks and Takizawa's request to become King, Japan is in a state of unrest economically and politically.During this journey, we revisit our familiar Selecaos trying to win the game in the own unique ways while being introduced to a new, and in my opinion annoying Selecao who serves no purpose to progressing the game's intent. Personally I would have loved to see the Supporter come out and waste him! We also witness another side to  Juiz who seems to have more personality and dare I say opinion when corresponding than the previous series. I do not want to give too much away so I will let you see the entire movie to understand what is going on...which takes me to my biggest gripe: The movie's overall plot progression and lack of understanding. The original series was a thinking person's anime that set us up with the major characters early and then slowly began to peel away the questions we might have asked with each Selcao we came across. Nothing was ever spelled out for us but there was just enough mystery to get us to the next episode while progressing the plot and having us figure out Takizawa's purpose and what was going on with this game. However, the first hour of this film sometimes drags tremendously for me.The search for Takizawa tends to be drawn out a bit while hearing about the political climate of Japan and trying to understand the peculiar actions of the other Selecao (you will  understand when you see it). When our hero finally turns up again, it seems to be a little too convenient in the plot.  In addition, I found myself scratching my head as to "why is he doing that" or "how did they get to be here" and 'doesn't this setting seem familar?" To me, the most interesting parts came from the Eden of the East crew trying to support Saki on her quest and then the final 10 minutes of the movie where the plot gets a sudden shot of adrenaline which takes us to the  conclusion...which really is an open door ending for the final movie delivering more questions than answers.I will say that the Bluray looks fantastic with Funimation delivering a very nice dub. The Japanese comes through clearly as well with crisp subtitles. I do suggest watching both the English and Japanese as  there are minor "reversions" that Funimation does in the translation to allow it to work for English speaking audiences. The extras are made up of trailers and tv spots but the special one is the movie "Air Communication" which was an edited version of the original series complete with commentary by the Eden of the East computer gang. It is only in Japanese with English subs but I tell you it is worth it. It supplies a beautiful refresher before the movies as well as explaining even more information. Definiltey a must see!Personally, I am giving this release a 3 out of 5 mainly because of the inclusion of Air Communication and the fact the Bluray looks and sounds beautifully. The feature film however was a lot to be desired in its pacing and overall execution. It is not a horrible movie, however, I feel the restrictions of a movie instead of say 6 or 7 episodes did not allow for the explanation of mystery that I adored from the first series...especially since the first hour was so under utilized before drop kicking us into the ending. Of course, there is one movie left so hopefully it will deliver on a overall satisfying conclusion.NOBLESSE OBLIGE!
summary: If you are a fan of the series, you might find this movie lacking

reviewText: This movie picks up where the first left off. We start to see the plans of the other selacao put into motion. Although this film is good, it has a very disappointing ending. Actually it has no ending. This anime just freakin stops. Just like His and Her Circumstances, Tsubasa, Spiral, and my beloved Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya. I want to sing praises for Eden of the East. I loved the series; but if this is it, they may as well have not made it at all. That's my only complaint. Everything about this anime is great. It just needs to be finished very badly.

reviewText: So as a fan of this series I was greatly anticipating this. In fact I checked on this way too many times. In the end I ended up watching it on Netflix and then buying it. The presentation is great, the movie is amazing. Minus the ending. I will not spoil much if anything in this review.So for all those who have seen the series I suggest that maybe you shouldnt watch the movies. Create your own ending, I can't completaly stick with this due to the fact that I have yet to see Paradise Lost. I can't wait for that either!! I continued to watch this because I adore Akira Takizawa.The movie goes around the fact that Saki is looking for Taki. Eden is now fully operational and almost everybody uses it!!! It's a huge corporation now. Saki goes out of her way to look for Taki often buying tickets to go back to the place where they first met due to his last message to her. Remember people?!?! He left her his phone when he erased his memory again!!! I really wish he'd stop doing that...Anyways despite Takizawa erasing his memory for the second time, he still tries to remember his past with his mother. Which leads to some really cute scenes with Taki and Saki. If you want to look at this is in a literal sense, then you really shouldnt be watching anime, let alone Eden XD. You know Taki, he's easy going and kind with his funny little attitude. So naturally when he meets Saki again, he's just like he was the last time she saw him, minus the fact that he doesnt know her. Saki uses an excuse and the two set off togeather, him believing that he is who she says he is because of the picture that he took of them.Along the way we finally meet a new member. In my opinion he's useless and lame and very unecessary, but then again this series is constantly surprising me. Also we find out each member has a Juiz, and each Juiz has a different personality. To me I believe his is just a jerk, Taki's sounds like it's ready to seduce him, and the Johnny hunter's is wonder why she has stopped cutting people's Johnnys off.All and I all I loved it, but I strongly STRONGLY suggest that you wait until Paradise Lost comes out, because of the ending. The ending is why it gets 4 stars. Good luck and enjoy.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Well if you enjoyed the series this movie is more of that but better, the animation is there and perfect, the focus on Akira's life before becoming a selecao, and Juiz gets more attention in the 2 films. King of Eden begins 6 months after the NEET Missile Crisis with Akira having his memory erased again. From there the identity of Akira is investigated and his search for answers about his past begins.A must buy for those who watched the series.Product Review: To clarify what exactly you get in this product. You get the movie King of Eden on DVD, Air Communication Film on DVD also on the same DVD are some extras. You also get King of Eden and Air Communication on Blu-Ray and the extras included on that disc. So you get 1 Blu-Ray, 2 DVDS, and the extras that come on each disc respectively. Probably one of the best values I have seen in a long time and hope to see most Blu-ray anime releases package a DVD copy with it. Also something to note is the case for this release is a DVD size case and not the thin and short Blu-ray case.Blu-Ray: Contains King of Eden, Air Communication, and Extras1st Dvd: Contains King of Eden2nd Dvd: Contains Air Communication and Extras

reviewText: Basically this follows on directly from the end of the main series and sees Saki searching for Takizawa.The movie is basically Sakis search for Takizawa and some random info on Juiz and the other Selecao and other random stuff that occurs during the movie to keep the audience interested.There is little to no reward for sitting through the movie as stated above, because the basic premise is she is looking for Akira, finds him, and goes home with him, all with the above to pad the movie out.I was expecting a little more action, and a little more than Akira has no memories(we knew this from the main series) and the fact that other Selecao are out to screw one another over.Sadly the movie is a let down if you're expecting a deep story, very little pay off, and very little to get excited about.It basically just plays as an extension to the main series, and given the length, would of been better served as being Episodes 12, 13, 14 and 15 had they decided to tack it on to the end instead of doing movies.
